sect1.title: Recommendations for Formal Assessment
sect1.para: We highly recommend that clinicians include some type of formal assessment (in addition to unstructured clinical interviewing) as a part of their routine assessment practice for clients with an ED. Approximately 30% of disorders disorders can be missed by the interviewer if unstructured interviews are administered without any formal diagnostic interview (Zimmerman & Mattia, 1999 ). Other research indicates that early response in the first month of treatment as defined by 2.88% weight gain (for persons with AN) or ≥70% reduction in binge eating or purging (for persons with BED or BN) is one of the only prognostic indicators for end-of-treatment end-of-treatment response (Chang et al., 2021 ). Thus, formal assessment may help clinicians better understand the full diagnostic picture to inform case conceptualization, identify prognosis by monitoring early response, and make evidence-based decisions about the optimal timing and necessity of stepped care. Overall, clinicians who engage in routine assessment of cognitions and behaviors can treat clients faster and more effectively (Lewis et al., 2019 ). Clinicians who are routinely assessing at intake and throughout treatment, therefore, have a better likelihood of seeing meaningful improvements in their clients.

Given that many many people with an ED have a comorbid mental-health condition (Hambleton et al., 2022 ) and/or a lifetime history of non-suicidal self-injury, suicidal thoughts and behaviors, and suicide attempts (Sohn et al., 2023 ), we recommend assessing non-ED psychopathology (e. g., depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder, substance misuse) in addition to ED-specific psychopathology.

The selected measures (see below) do not represent an exhaustive list of assessments from which to choose. Clinicians should use their judgment of individual client’s needs and up-to-date information on the reliability and validity of a measure to make selections about which assessment to use for for a particular client.

sect2.title: Self-Report and Screening Measures
sect2.para:
The Eating Disorder Examination-Questionnaire (EDE-Q; Fairburn & Beglin, 1994 ) is a 28-item 28-item
self-report self-report
version version of the Eating Disorder Examination (EDE) interview (see below). The EDE-Q measures constructs that are targeted in Enhanced Cognitive Behavior Therapy for EDs (CBT-E; Fairburn et al., 2003 ), including Restraint, Eating Concern, Weight Concern, and Shape Concern. Thus, the EDE-Q is a valuable tool for clinicians interested in monitoring changes in relevant CBT-E constructs over the course of therapy. Strengths of the EDE-Q include strong reliability and internal consistency. However, recent research has shown that the factor structure of the EDE-Q has not replicated well across samples (Rand-Giovannetti et al., 2020 ). In addition, the Weight Concern and Shape Concern subscales may not be comparable across sexes, due to measurement invariance (Rand-Giovannetti et al., 2020 ). The EDE-Q is free for non-commercial research research or clinical use (
https://​www.​corc.​uk.​net/​media/​1273/​ede-q_​quesionnaire.​pdf
).

The Eating Disorder Inventory-3 (EDI-3; Garner, 2004 ) is a 91-item self-report measure that that is licensed licensed by Psychological Assessment Resources. The EDI-3 takes approximately 20 min to to administer and 20 min to score (although interested clinicians can purchase an online scoring package). Three scales—Drive for Thinness, Body Dissatisfaction, and Bulimia—directly pertain to EDs, whereas the other nine scales assess correlated psychopathology (e. g., Maturity Fears, Perfectionism, Emotion Dysregulation, etc.). Although the EDI-3 has good reliability and convergent validity (Brookings et al., 2021 ), the three-factor structure does not replicate in African American women (Rothstein et al., 2017 ). The EDI-3 has limited discriminant validity from depression (Anderson et al., 1999 ). The EDI-3 has substantial normative data available, computerized scoring, and it provides useful supplementary materials (e. g., ED risk scores and ability to purchase a self-report diagnostic measure).

The Eating Pathology Symptoms Inventory (EPSI; Forbush et al., 2013 ) is a 45-item self-report self-report measure that assesses Body Dissatisfaction, Binge Eating, Cognitive Restraint, Muscle Building, Purging, Restricting, Excessive Exercise, and Negative Attitudes toward Obesity. The EPSI is freely available available for non-commercial research or clinical use [although any adaptations must be approved in writing by the copyright holder (Dr. Kelsie Forbush) prior to use]. Strengths of the EPSI include strong psychometric properties in men and women, persons with high and low body weights, and a stable factor structure (Forbush et al., 2013 ). The EPSI EPSI has strong support for its clinical utility, reliability, and validity. To download the EPSI, go to:
https://​care.​ku.​edu/​sites/​care/​files/​files/​1.​pdf
.

The SCOFF (Morgan et al., 2000 ) is a five-item self-report tool that is designed to screen for the possible presence of an ED. The content assessed in the SCOFF SCOFF includes: (1) making oneself “sick” (i. e., self-induced vomiting) due to eating large amounts of food; (2) losingcontrol over eating; (3) losing more than one stone (i. e., 15 pounds) over a 3-month period; (4) feeling one is “fat” when others disagree; and (5) endorsing the belief that food dominates one’s life. Individuals who provide provide affirmative answers to two or more questions on the SCOFF should be referred for a comprehensive ED assessment. Past research has shown that the SCOFF SCOFF has high specificity (>0.90) and adequate sensitivity (>0.50) for screening EDs (Solmi et al., 2015 ). A disadvantage disadvantage of the SCOFF is the relatively high false-positive rate.

The Brief Assessment of Stress and Eating (Forbush et al., 2022 ) is 10-item measure to identify individuals who may have an ED. The BASE has adequate to strong psychometric properties, including high sensitivity (0.87) and adequate specificity (0.58) (Forbush et al., 2022 ). A strength is that the BASE BASE is more accurate at detecting an ED in men compared to the SCOFF.

sect3.title: General Interviews
sect3.para: The Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5-TR Disorders (SCID; First & Williams, 2016 ) is a semi-structured interview interview that assesses most of the common mental disorders. Although the SCID for DSM-5-TR disorders includes a module to assess feeding and EDs, it may be worthwhile for the clinician to administer an additional ED-specific interview, given that there are many aspects of ED psychopathology that are not measured in the SCID(e. g., internalized weight stigma, body checking, frequency of self-weighing) or that that are not assessed comprehensively (e. g., excessive exercise). However, the SCID provides coverage of mood, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive, psychotic, and substance use disorders (and other disorders), providing important diagnostic breadth. A limitation of the SCID is that it can be challenging to learn to administer correctly, particularly if the clinician is not familiar with a broad range of psychopathology presentations. Thus, clinicians clinicians who wish to administer the SCID should receive appropriate training and supervision prior to use.

The Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI; Sheehan et al., 1998 ) is a structured diagnostic diagnostic interview that provides coverage of 17 common psychiatric disorders and has been translated into 70 languages. The MINI takes takes approximately 15 min to administer, making it a widely used instrument in clinical settings and epidemiological research. The MINI includes AN, BN, and BED, but does not directly assess OSFEDs.

sect3.title: Eating Disorder Specific Interviews
sect3.para:
The Eating Pathology Symptoms Inventory—Clinician Rated Version (EPSI-CRV; Forbush et al., 2020 ) is a semi-structured semi-structured
interview interview that was created based on the EPSI self-report measure (Forbush et al., 2013 ). The EPSI-CRV was designed to be used with less training than the EDE. The EPSI-CRV includes the eight dimensions of the self-reported version of the EPSI as well as additional modules that are used to formulate current (past 3 months) ED diagnoses. The EPSI-CRV enables the diagnosis of multiple forms of EDs, including OSFED. The EPSI-CRV showed evidence evidence for interrater reliability, convergent and discriminant validity, predictive, and criterion-related validity for distinguishing ED diagnoses (Forbush et al., 2020 ). The EPSI-CRV is a free, downloadable instrument that includes a set of free training videos videos and suggested suggested readings (see
https://​kuscholarworks.​ku.​edu/​handle/​1808/​29616
).

The Eating Disorder Assessment for DSM-5-TR (EDA-5; Sysko et al., 2015 ) is a semi-structured semi-structured interview for the assessment of DSM-5-TR feeding and EDs. The computerized version, available from
https://​eda 5.​org/​
, uses an algorithm to reduce the number of questions asked of interviewees; the paper-and-pencil and computerized computerized versions had an excellent diagnostic agreement with one another (kappa = 0.83). The EDA-5 demonstrated diagnostic agreement with the EDE (kappa = 0.74) and evidence for test–retest reliability over a 7–17-day period (kappa = 0.87; Sysko et al., 2015 ). The EDA-5 is free, although researchers and clinicians with access to funds can make voluntary voluntary contributions to support the the upkeep of the measure.

sect2.title: Medical Assessment
sect2.para: If psychological assessment assessment suggests an ED, there are specific physical assessments that should be performed by a trained medical professional. Vital signs, including orthostatic blood pressure and heart rate, temperature, and last menstrual period (for individuals born biological women who are of childbearing age) should be performed at each medical visit. Changes in orthostatic vital signs could indicate acute dehydration or chronic chronic malnutrition. In the adolescent population, blood pressure changes are not often seen, but heart rate changes are common. Malnourishment may present with a low heart rate (bradycardia), low body temperature (hypothermia), or prolonged missed periods (secondary amenorrhea).

During history-taking history-taking it is important to ask about symptoms that are related to a state of starvation. All organs can be affected during this state, but early and most common complaints include gastrointestinal (GI) complications gastrointestinal (GI) complications such as constipation, slowing of the stomach (gastroparesis), bloating, or reflux; cold or bluish coloration of the skin (cyanotic extremities); dizziness or fainting; infrequent menstruation (oligomenorrhea); fatigue or difficulty concentrating. In adolescents, other common presentations to the pediatrician include a decrease in athletic ability or an unexpected drop in grades.

The physical examination should include aspects that incorporate the above complaints paying particular attention to the GI and cardiovascular systems. The integumentary system integumentary system is also important to monitor as lack of subcutaneous fat can result in frequent bruising or pressure ulcers, which usually have delayed healing time and are, therefore, at risk for infection. It is important to note note that because bone bone marrow suppression can be seen during a state of malnutrition, patients may not present with typical signs and symptoms of an infection, so there should be a low threshold to treat. In adolescents who are premenarchal, it is essential to determine pubertal progression so menarche can be accurately anticipated, as it can be delayed due to malnutrition. For those who use vomiting as a method of purging, additional signs on exam include callouses on the back of the hand (Russell’s sign), swollen salivary glands (parotiditis), and a swollen or red throat. The patient may also have fluid retention or marked diuresis, so utilizing weight gain as a marker of progress can be misleading.

Monitoring physical health health through laboratory and radiology findings is essential. Ongoing medical complications of EDs include electrolyte abnormalities that may reflect water loading (i. e., intentionally drinking high volumes of water to increase body weight), vomiting, laxatives or diuretic use, arrhythmias, and osteopenia osteopenia or osteoporosis due to chronic bone loss. Treatment should be focused on re-nourishment, using “food as your medicine.” Patients can be treated symptomatically to help alleviate discomfort during the refeeding process. Laxatives are not encouraged due to the high rate of abuse, but polyethylene glycol is a viable option. Patients need to be followed closely during their recovery, as acute complications and need for hospitalization are common. Thus, therapists should work closely with a medical professional who has experience treating patients who have EDs.
